expanded_description: Review questions provide practice and reinforcement of key measurement concepts from Chapter 2. These problems test understanding of the metric system, SI units, unit conversions, dimensional analysis, and measurements of length, area, volume, density, time, and temperature.

core_concept.principle: Review questions synthesize and apply the measurement concepts learned throughout the chapter, testing both conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills.
core_concept.explanation: This section brings together all the measurement topics: the metric system's decimal structure, SI base and derived units, conversion techniques, dimensional analysis for error checking, and practical measurements of physical quantities. Success requires understanding both the underlying concepts (why we use SI units, what dimensions mean) and the procedural skills (how to convert units, calculate density, use formulas). The questions progress from basic recall to application and analysis, mirroring how measurement skills are used in real physics problems.

sections.introduction: These questions test your grasp of fundamental measurement concepts without requiring extensive calculations.

key_concept.definition: Conceptual questions assess understanding of principles, relationships, and reasoning rather than computational skills.
key_concept.context: Being able to explain why something is true is just as important as being able to calculate an answer. These questions develop deeper understanding.

worked_examples.title: Question 1: Metric System Advantages
worked_examples.problem: List three advantages of the metric system over traditional measurement systems like the imperial system.

step_by_step.explanation: Metric uses powers of 10 for all conversions. 1 km = 1000 m, 1 m = 100 cm. Imperial uses irregular factors: 1 mile = 5280 feet, 1 foot = 12 inches.
Metric is used worldwide by scientists and in almost all countries, ensuring universal communication.
Same prefixes work with all units: kilo- always means 1000 (kilometer, kilogram, kilowatt). Makes learning easier.

worked_examples.final_answer: Three advantages: (1) All conversions use powers of 10, making calculations easy. (2) Universal international standard ensures clear communication. (3) Consistent prefixes apply across all units, reducing memorization.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Understanding why the metric system was adopted and why it's superior for scientific work.

worked_examples.title: Question 2: Base vs Derived Units
worked_examples.problem: Explain the difference between base units and derived units. Give two examples of each.

step_by_step.explanation: Base units are the seven fundamental SI units defined independently, not in terms of other units.
Meter (m) for length, kilogram (kg) for mass, second (s) for time, Kelvin (K) for temperature.
Derived units are combinations of base units formed by multiplication, division, or exponentiation.
Square meter (m²) for area, meter per second (m/s) for velocity, kilogram per cubic meter (kg/m³) for density, Newton (kg·m/s²) for force.

worked_examples.final_answer: Base units are fundamental, independent units (examples: meter, kilogram, second, Kelvin). Derived units are combinations of base units (examples: m² for area, m/s for velocity, kg/m³ for density, N = kg·m/s² for force).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Understanding the structure of the SI system—base units as building blocks, derived units as combinations.

worked_examples.title: Question 3: Dimensions in Equations
worked_examples.problem: Why must both sides of a physics equation have the same dimensions? What does it tell us if they don't match?

step_by_step.explanation: Physical equations represent true relationships between quantities. You can only equate quantities of the same type.
Just as you can't add apples to oranges and get apples, you can't add length to time and get length. Dimensions must match.
If dimensions don't match, the equation is definitely wrong—there's an error in the physics or mathematics.
Matching dimensions is necessary but not sufficient—the equation might still be wrong (wrong numerical coefficient or wrong physics).

worked_examples.final_answer: Both sides must have the same dimensions because equations represent true physical relationships between quantities of the same type. If dimensions don't match, the equation is definitely wrong—it violates the basic principle that you can only equate like quantities. Dimensional consistency is a necessary (but not sufficient) condition for correctness.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Understanding dimensional analysis as an error-checking tool and the principle of dimensional consistency.

worked_examples.title: Question 4: Temperature vs Heat
worked_examples.problem: Explain the difference between temperature and heat. Use an example to illustrate.

step_by_step.explanation: Temperature measures the average kinetic energy of particles—how hot something is. It's intensive (doesn't depend on amount).
Heat is thermal energy transferred between objects due to temperature difference. It's measured in Joules and is extensive (depends on amount).
A cup of boiling water (100°C) has higher temperature than a bathtub of warm water (40°C). But the bathtub contains far more thermal energy because it has much more water, even though it's cooler.
Temperature tells you intensity (how hot). Heat tells you quantity (how much energy transferred).

worked_examples.final_answer: Temperature measures average particle kinetic energy (intensity, intensive property). Heat is thermal energy transfer (quantity, extensive property, measured in Joules). Example: Boiling water in a cup has higher temperature (100°C) than a warm bathtub (40°C), but the bathtub contains more total thermal energy due to its much greater mass.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Distinguishing between intensive properties (temperature) and extensive quantities (thermal energy/heat).

worked_examples.title: Question 5: Density as Material Property
worked_examples.problem: Why is density considered a characteristic property of matter? How can this be used to identify substances?

step_by_step.explanation: A characteristic property is one that's the same for a given pure substance regardless of sample size—it identifies the material.
Density = mass/volume. For a pure substance, this ratio is constant. A drop of water and a liter of water both have density 1.0 g/cm³.
Each pure material has its own characteristic density at given conditions: gold = 19.3 g/cm³, aluminum = 2.7 g/cm³, water = 1.0 g/cm³.
Measure mass and volume of unknown sample, calculate density, compare to known values to identify the material.

worked_examples.final_answer: Density is characteristic because each pure substance has a unique, constant density regardless of sample size (intensive property). By measuring an unknown material's density and comparing to known values, we can identify the substance or detect impurities.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Understanding density as an intensive, characteristic property useful for material identification.

sections.introduction: Practice converting between different units using conversion factors and proper techniques.

worked_examples.title: Question 6: Length Conversions
worked_examples.problem: Convert the following: (a) 3.5 km to meters, (b) 850 mm to centimeters, (c) 0.025 m to micrometers.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Using metric prefix relationships for length conversions.

worked_examples.title: Question 7: Area Conversion
worked_examples.problem: A room has an area of 25 m². Convert this to (a) cm², (b) mm².

step_by_step.explanation: For area, SQUARE the linear conversion factor!

worked_examples.concept_applied: Area conversions require squaring the linear conversion factor.

worked_examples.title: Question 8: Volume Conversion
worked_examples.problem: Convert: (a) 2.5 L to mL, (b) 500 cm³ to L, (c) 0.003 m³ to liters.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Volume conversions: 1 L = 1000 mL = 1000 cm³, 1 m³ = 1000 L.

worked_examples.title: Question 9: Time Conversion
worked_examples.problem: Convert: (a) 4.5 hours to seconds, (b) 250 ms to seconds, (c) 1.5 years to seconds (use 365.25 days/year).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Time conversions: 1 h = 3600 s, 1 year ≈ 3.156 × 10⁷ s.

worked_examples.title: Question 10: Speed Unit Conversion
worked_examples.problem: A car travels at 100 km/h. Convert this to m/s.

step_by_step.explanation: Divide km/h by 3.6 to get m/s: 100 ÷ 3.6 = 27.8 m/s

worked_examples.final_answer: 100 km/h = 27.8 m/s (approximately 28 m/s)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Converting derived units: convert numerator and denominator separately. Quick rule: km/h ÷ 3.6 = m/s.

sections.introduction: Apply measurement formulas to solve problems involving area, volume, and density.

worked_examples.title: Question 11: Area Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A rectangular garden is 12.5 m long and 8.0 m wide. Find (a) the area in m², (b) the area in cm².
worked_examples.concept_applied: Rectangle area: A = l × w. Area conversions square the linear factor.

worked_examples.title: Question 12: Volume Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A cylindrical water tank has radius 1.5 m and height 4.0 m. Calculate its volume in (a) m³, (b) liters.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Cylinder volume: V = πr²h. Volume conversions: 1 m³ = 1000 L.

worked_examples.title: Question 13: Density Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A metal cube with sides of 2.0 cm has a mass of 62.4 g. Calculate its density in (a) g/cm³, (b) kg/m³. (c) Identify the metal (use: aluminum = 2.7 g/cm³, copper = 8.96 g/cm³, iron = 7.87 g/cm³).

step_by_step.explanation: 7.8 g/cm³ is closest to iron (7.87 g/cm³). The metal is likely iron or steel.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) 7.8 g/cm³, (b) 7800 kg/m³, (c) The metal is iron (or steel)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Density = mass/volume. Use density to identify materials.

worked_examples.title: Question 14: Finding Mass from Density
worked_examples.problem: A container holds 2.5 L of mercury. Mercury has density 13.6 g/cm³. What is the mass of the mercury in kg?
worked_examples.final_answer: Mass = 34 kg (mercury is very dense and heavy!)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Rearrange ρ = m/V to get m = ρV. Convert units as needed.

worked_examples.title: Question 15: Finding Volume from Density
worked_examples.problem: A gold nugget has mass 386 g. Gold's density is 19.3 g/cm³. What is the nugget's volume?

step_by_step.explanation: 20 cm³ is a relatively small volume (like a large marble) for nearly 400 g—shows gold's high density.

worked_examples.final_answer: Volume = 20 cm³
worked_examples.concept_applied: Rearrange ρ = m/V to get V = m/ρ when finding volume.

sections.introduction: Practice temperature conversions and applications of temperature concepts.

worked_examples.title: Question 16: Temperature Conversions
worked_examples.problem: Convert the following temperatures: (a) 25°C to Kelvin, (b) 310 K to Celsius, (c) 68°F to Celsius, (d) -40°C to Fahrenheit.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Temperature scale conversions using standard formulas.

worked_examples.title: Question 17: Temperature Change
worked_examples.problem: Water is heated from 15°C to 85°C. What is the temperature change in (a) Celsius degrees, (b) Kelvins?

step_by_step.explanation: Since Celsius and Kelvin have the same degree size, ΔT is the same
step_by_step.calculation: ΔT = 70 K (numerically equal to 70°C for temperature changes)

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) ΔT = 70°C, (b) ΔT = 70 K (same numerical value)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Temperature changes: ΔT in °C = ΔT in K because degree sizes are equal.

sections.introduction: Use dimensional analysis to check equations and derive relationships.

worked_examples.title: Question 18: Checking Equation Validity
worked_examples.problem: Check if the equation E = mv is dimensionally consistent, where E is energy, m is mass, and v is velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: m has [M], v has [LT⁻¹]. So mv has [M][LT⁻¹] = [MLT⁻¹]
The equation is dimensionally inconsistent and therefore wrong. The correct equation is E = ½mv² (dimensions: [M][LT⁻¹]² = [ML²T⁻²] ✓)

worked_examples.final_answer: No, E = mv is NOT dimensionally consistent. Correct equation: E = ½mv².
worked_examples.concept_applied: Dimensional analysis detects equation errors by checking if dimensions match.

worked_examples.title: Question 19: Finding Dimensions
worked_examples.problem: The power P delivered by a force F moving at velocity v is given by P = Fv. Show that this is dimensionally consistent.
worked_examples.final_answer: Yes, dimensionally consistent. Both sides have dimensions [ML²T⁻³].
worked_examples.concept_applied: Verify dimensional consistency by expressing all quantities in fundamental dimensions.

sections.introduction: More complex problems requiring integration of multiple concepts and multi-step reasoning.

worked_examples.title: Question 20: Multi-Step Density Problem
worked_examples.problem: A rectangular metal sheet is 50 cm long, 30 cm wide, and 2 mm thick. It has a mass of 2.43 kg. (a) Calculate the volume in m³. (b) Calculate the density in kg/m³. (c) Will it float in water? (d) Identify the metal.

step_by_step.explanation: Convert all to meters: l = 0.50 m, w = 0.30 m, h = 0.002 m
Water density = 1000 kg/m³. Metal density = 8100 kg/m³ > 1000 kg/m³
step_by_step.calculation: Metal is denser than water, so it will SINK.

step_by_step.explanation: 8100 kg/m³ = 8.1 g/cm³. Close to copper (8.96 g/cm³) or brass (~8.4-8.7 g/cm³). Likely brass or bronze.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) 3 × 10⁻⁴ m³, (b) 8100 kg/m³, (c) Sinks (denser than water), (d) Likely brass or bronze
worked_examples.concept_applied: Combining volume calculation, density calculation, buoyancy principles, and material identification.

summary: Chapter 2 review questions integrate all measurement topics: the metric system's advantages (decimal basis, universal use, consistent prefixes), SI base units (meter, kilogram, second, Kelvin) versus derived units (m², m³, m/s, kg/m³, N, J), unit conversion techniques (conversion factors, squaring for area, cubing for volume), dimensional analysis for error checking (dimensions must match on both sides of equations), and practical measurements (area = length × width for rectangles, A = πr² for circles; volume = l × w × h for boxes, V = πr²h for cylinders, V = 4πr³/3 for spheres; density ρ = m/V for material properties). Temperature conversions use K = °C + 273.15, °F = (9/5)°C + 32, with temperature changes equal in Celsius and Kelvin (ΔT in °C = ΔT in K). Problem-solving requires understanding concepts (why metric system works, difference between temperature and heat, density as characteristic property), procedural skills (converting units, calculating area/volume/density), and integration (multi-step problems combining several concepts). Success depends on both conceptual understanding and computational facility, always checking units and reasonableness of answers.
